metadata.sermon_start_end: Likely you know this text from Habakkuk, even if you have not been reading Habakkuk lately: The LORD is in his holy temple; let all the earth keep silence before him. (Hab. 2:20) The scene is the awesome Jerusalem temple where the great God, maker of heaven and earth [...] But we know a more excellent way; and we have to speak about it!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker's requirement of focusing on ONE specific passage. It treats the Amos text as a thematic springboard and then pivots to Colossians and Luke. It becomes a speech about 'silence and speech' rather than an exposition of what is unique to the Amos pericope.
quotes: So consider two texts wherein the God of the gospel will not be silent.
The combination of Jesus talk... and neighbor talk... is a dangerous compelling articulation.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one pericope (e.g., Amos 7:10-17) and find the 'unique point' that exists nowhere else in Scripture, rather than harmonizing it with the Lectionary.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher shows awareness of the historical-political tension between Amos (South) and Amaziah (North/Bethel). However, it lacks the depth of Greek/Hebrew nuance Dekker expects from a trained theologian.
quotes: The high priest, an agent of the king, reported to the king that Amos was a traitor...
He came from the south, from Judah. For reasons that we do not know, he did his work in the north.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the linguistic analysis of the 'conspiracy' (qashar) or the 'plumb line' (if included) to show the specific theological weight of the original Hebrew context.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is strong and concrete, identifying specific modern 'silencers' like consumerism and white nationalism. It avoids the 'general truths' Dekker forbids.
quotes: Our silencing is accomplished by the narcotic of consumer goods...
The silencing of such a tale is because such neighbor talk is dangerous to the high culture of white nationalism.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows directly from the specific text's uniqueness rather than general prophetic themes.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured in blocks (I, II, III). While the application is sharp, it feels like a second movement rather than being 'mixed' into the exposition as Dekker demands.
quotes: That contest is as urgent now. We live in a society that...
So consider two texts wherein the God of the gospel will not be silent.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Draw the hearer into the Amos/Amaziah conflict immediately as a mirror of their own world, rather than explaining the history first and applying it later.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The 'misery' of the status quo and the 'redemption' of the Jesus-reality are present. However, the 'gratitude' (the life of the believer) is framed more as a social duty than a Spirit-awakened response.
quotes: The news about Jesus is a word of truth and a word of hope.
We will insist on the talk and on the walk in public places.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ground the 'walk' more clearly in the 'gratitude' awakened by the Spirit to avoid moralism.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon takes the 'two ways' seriously, emphasizing the 'temporal loss' of a society that perishes through injustice. It presents life as a journey with a purpose.
quotes: Life turned in on ourselves will shrivel to our frightened tribe.
Conduct and policy have consequences, and you need to know about them.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Connect the temporal loss of society more explicitly to the 'eternal' weight of standing before God, as Dekker suggests the two complement each other.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the 'telos' in the third section, but he feels like an addition to the Amos theme rather than the inherent goal of the specific Scripture passage.
quotes: Jesus is the first-born of creation... the giver of grace.
The silencing of the Jesus-reality among us is not by censure... but by distortion.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Show how the specific Amos text points to Christ as its telos, rather than bringing in Colossians to do the 'Christ-work'.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1450 words, the sermon lasts roughly 14-15 minutes. According to Dekker, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for true depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exposition and application to reach the 20-minute threshold to allow the 'present of revelation' to emerge.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short primarily on formal grounds: it lacks a single-text focus and is too short (approx. 15 minutes). While it is rhetorically strong and avoids generalities, it functions more as a thematic address on 'prophetic speech' than a specific 'exposition and application' of the Amos pericope.
strengths: Concrete application to contemporary issues like consumerism and nationalism.
Clear identification of the 'misery' of the status quo.
Avoids the 'librarian' top-down notion of God in favor of a living Voice.
weaknesses: Fragmentation caused by using three different Lectionary texts.
Insufficient length to achieve the 'breadth' Dekker requires.
Separation of exposition and application into distinct sections.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an effective prophetic speech, but according to Dekker's strict criteria, it is not yet a 'sermon' because it lacks a singular scriptural anchor and the necessary duration for theological depth.
